The final answer is the minimum number of moves required to make the array strictly increasing.

The code provided in the problem has an outer loop from 1 to n. For each i, they set now=0 and lst=0. Then there's a loop that's missing (the TODO part). Then another loop from j=i+1 to n computes the required steps.

The missing loop is for the first part of the array up to i.

The correct code should be:

for (long long j=1; j<=i; ++j) {
    // compute steps for the first part
    // ...
}

Thus, the missing loop is for the first part of the array up to i.

The correct code should be:

for (long long j=1; j<=i; ++j) {
    now += lst/a[j]+1;
    lst = a[j]*(lst/a[j]+1);
}

Then, the second loop from j=i+1 to n computes the required steps for the rest of the array.

The final code should be:

#include<algorithm>
#include<cstdio>
using namespace std;
long long n, ans=1e18, now, lst;
int main(){
    scanf("%d", &n);
    for (long long i=1; i<=n; ++i) {
        now = 0;
        lst = 0;
        // Compute steps for the first part up to i
        for (long long j=1; j<=i; ++j) {
            now += lst/a[j]+1;
            lst = a[j]*(lst/a[j]+1);
        }
        // Compute steps for the rest of the array
        for (long long j=i+1; j<=n; ++j) {
            now += lst/a[j]+1;
            lst = a[j]*(lst/a[j]+1);
        }
        ans = min(ans, now);
    }
    printf("%lld\n", ans);
    return 0;
}
